I'm following this thread to compile mxnet on TX1. I encountered this error:

g++: error: /home/nvidia/ml/mxnet/dmlc-core/libdmlc.a: No such file or directory

make: **\* [lib/libmxnet.so] Error 1
make: **\* Waiting for unfinished jobs....
g++: error: /home/nvidia/ml/mxnet/dmlc-core/libdmlc.a: No such file or directory
Makefile:205: recipe for target 'bin/im2rec' failed
make: **\* [bin/im2rec] Error 1

Anyone had the same error previously?
is PCI-E topology being exploited in the reduction in current PR?

I runned a test program using tensorflow.
It runs normal, starting very fast.

merge as lint passed, There is a documentation error that is yet to be fixed by ImperativeInvoke https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet/jobs/158363420

@piiswrong Please fix it in your next PR

i am pr 
https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/pull/40
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3255

Hi @javelinjs 

I still encountered the `cudnn` issue. In my `config.mk` I've already turned off the `cudnn` option. 

``` bash
 40 # whether use CUDA during compile
 41 USE_CUDA = 1
 42
 43 # add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag
 44 # if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
 45 USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda-7.5
 46 # USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE
 47
 48 # whether use CuDNN R3 library
 49 USE_CUDNN = 0
```

But still have this problem.
@geraint0923  is this using gcc 4.8?

but. i have some problem.
the nnvm lib "LinkLibraryDependencies" and "UseLibraryDependencyInputs" must set to true.
but cmake can't set it. only can manually set in the visual studio.
put this into the install doc. or I try to use a python script to set it.
Are you loading model which is trained with cudnn?

@javelinjs Sorry for bothering you, I've skip this cudnn problem by remove this element in my json. Another question after that, I got some problem in reshape. The input shape and target shape always can not be matched.

My input shape should be (128, 20), then embedding should get (128, 1, 20, 128), which is 327680; but I always got:

> [20:49:45] /Users/lewis/Workspace/source-codes/release/mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:245: [20:49:45] src/operator/./reshape-inl.h:122: Check failed: oshape.Size() == dshape.Size() Target shape size is different to source. Target: 327680
> Source: 16384

I use scala-pkg by simply add a maven dependency in IntelliJ, I was success in running a cnn4text with pretrain-embedding before, in which its input is (128, 1, 20, 128); but when I change to this(without embedding) setting, it's wrong. 

Is it possible related with the deprecated `target_shape` argument? I've mentioned I use the symbol.json file from different libmxnet.so, that true because I use python to train and maven(scala) in production.

I encountered a similar problem. I converted MNIST binary data to jpg images, and then packed jpg images to an ImageRecord binary file. However, the training accuracy was always about 0.114844, which is just a random guess.

I referred to http://mxnet.io/packages/python/io.html#create-dataset-using-recordio to pack images to ImageRecord binary. My command is:
`python ~/packages/mxnet/tools/im2rec.py --color 0 --quality 100 --shuffle True "" jpg`

Then I used a MLP for training:

```
import mxnet as mx
import logging
import os

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

home = os.path.expanduser("~")
prefix = home + "/dataset/"

train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec=prefix + "mnist/train-images-idx3.rec",
    data_shape=(1,28,28),
    batch_size = 128,
    shuffle=True,
)

data = mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=128)
act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc1, act_type="relu")
fc2  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=act1, num_hidden=64)
act2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc2, act_type="relu")
fc3  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=act2, num_hidden=10)
mlp  = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, name="softmax")

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    symbol = mlp,
    num_epoch = 20,
    learning_rate = .1,
)

model.fit(X=train,
          eval_metric=["accuracy"],
          batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(128),
          logger=logger)
```

@javelinjs I use Python to train the model. Then use its outputs(symbol & params) in java env, in which I write some simple scala-code and use java to call them.

### Python code in training - Network definition.

``` python
111 # single non-static network
112 def get_non_static_net(vocab_size, embedding_size, sentence_size, batch_size, num_intent_classes, with_embedding, dropout=0.0, filter_list=[1,2,3], num_filter=100):
113     """
114     CNN with multichannel.
115     """
116
117     data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
119     label_intent = mx.symbol.Variable('softmax_label_intent')
120
121     # embedding layer. non-static
122     word_embed_nonstatic = mx.symbol.Embedding(data=data, input_dim=vocab_size,
123                                                output_dim=embedding_size,
124                                                name='word_embedding_nonstatic')
125     word_embed_nonstatic = mx.symbol.Reshape(data=word_embed_nonstatic, name='reshape_after_embedding',
126                                              shape=(batch_size, 1, sentence_size, embedding_size))  # convolution layer needs 4D input.
127     # concat them as conv_input
128     conv_input = word_embed_nonstatic
129
130     # convolution and pooling layer
131     pooled_outputs = []
132     for i, filter_size in enumerate(filter_list):
133         convi = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=conv_input, kernel=(filter_size, embedding_size), num_filter=num_filter)
134         acti  = mx.symbol.Activation(data=convi, act_type='relu')
135         pooli = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=acti, pool_type='max', kernel=(sentence_size - filter_size + 1, 1), stride=(1,1))  # max pooling on entire sentence feature ma    p.
136         pooled_outputs.append(pooli)
137
138     # combine all pooled outputs
139     num_feature_maps = num_filter * len(filter_list)
140     concat = mx.symbol.Concat(*pooled_outputs, dim=1)  # max-overtime pooling. concat all feature maps into a long feature before feeding into final dropout and full    y connected layer.
141     h_pool = mx.symbol.Reshape(data=concat, shape=(batch_size, num_feature_maps))  # make it flat/horizontal
142
143     # dropout
144     if dropout > 0.0:
145         logging.info('use dropout.')
146         drop = mx.symbol.Dropout(data=h_pool, p=dropout)
147     else:
148         logging.info('Do not use dropout.')
149         drop = h_pool
150
151     # fully connected and softmax output.
153     fc_intent = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=drop, num_hidden=num_intent_classes, name='fc_intent')
155     softmax_intent = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc_intent, label=label_intent)
156
157     return softmax_intent
```

### Serving side - Use Scala and Java

Create a MXNetPredictor.scala to provide `predict` function. Then use Java to pass features/data.

``` scala
class MXNetPredictor (prefix: String, epoch: Int, batchSize: Int) {

  private val logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(classOf[MXNetPredictor])

  val model = FeedForward.load(prefix, epoch)

  /**
    * predict
    *
    * @param flat A flat feature input vector.
    * @param shape Shape of input data.
    * @return
    */
  def predict(flat: Array[Float], shape: Array[Int]): Array[NDArray] = {
    val ndArray = NDArray.array(flat, Shape(shape))

    val data: IndexedSeq[NDArray] = IndexedSeq(ndArray)
    val label: IndexedSeq[NDArray] = IndexedSeq()

    val inputBatchSize = shape(0)
    if (inputBatchSize != batchSize) {
      logger.error("Input data shape should be consistent with your batchSize.")
      logger.error("batchSize: " + batchSize)
      logger.error("Input data shape: " + inputBatchSize)
    } else {
      val valData: NDArrayIter = new NDArrayIter(data, label, batchSize)
      val prediction = model.predict(valData)
      return prediction
    }
    null
  }
```

At Java side, I also provide a prediction API.

``` java
public String predict(String utterance) {
        float[] features = generateFeature(utterance);
        int[] shape = {batchSize, 1, sentenceSize, embeddingSize};
        NDArray prediction = predictor.predict(features, shape);  // predictor is MXNetPredictor.scala

        int index = (int) prediction.toArray()[0];
        return xxx;
    }
```

Currently the scala-package of mxnet only supports Scala 2.10.
The newest version of Scala is 2.11, and 2.12 will be out in a few months. Scala 2.10/11/12 are NOT binary compatible, meaning the jars cannot be shared across Scala versions.
It's good if something can be set in the pom.xml or build.sbt to enable cross-building to Scala 2.11 (and potentially 2.12 in the near future).

I've written a wrapper for RNN in the python side, which uses this type of layout. I may PR after repeating the accuracy of the NLP task.

``` python
class RNN(object):
    """High level API for constructing stacked RNN layers.

    To use a recurrent neural network, we can first create an RNN object and use the step function
    during the symbol construction.

    Currently four types of RNN are supported and all parameters per layer are grouped into 4 matrices.
    The data layout and transition rules are similar to the RNN API in CuDNN (https://developer.nvidia.com/cudnn)
    1) ReLU RNN:
        h_t = ReLU(W_i x_t + R_i h_{t-1} + b_{W_i} + b_{R_i})

        Parameters:
            W_{i2h} = W_i
            b_{i2h} = b_{W_i}
            W_{h2h} = R_i
            b_{h2h} = b_{R_i}
    2) Tanh RNN:
        h_t = tanh(W_i x_t + R_i h_{t-1} + b_{W_i} + b_{R_i})

        Parameters:
            W_{i2h} = W_i
            b_{i2h} = b_{W_i}
            W_{h2h} = R_i
            b_{h2h} = b_{R_i}
    3) LSTM:
        i_t = \sigma(W_i x_t + R_i h_{t-1} + b_{W_i} + b_{R_i})
        f_t = \sigma(W_f x_t + R_f h_{t-1} + b_{W_f} + b_{R_f})
        o_t = \sigma(W_o x_t + R_o h_{t-1} + b_{W_o} + b_{R_o})
        c^\prime_t = tanh(W_c x_t + R_c h_{t-1} + b_{W_c} + b_{R_c})
        c_t = f_t \circ c_{t-1} + i_t \circ c^\prime_t
        h_t = o_t \circ tanh(c_t)

        Parameters: (input_gate, forget_gate, new_mem, output_gate)
            W_{i2h} = [W_i, W_f, W_c, W_o]
            b_{i2h} = [b_{W_i}, b_{W_f}, b_{W_c}, b_{W_o}]
            W_{h2h} = [R_i, R_f, R_c, R_o]
            b_{h2h} = [b_{R_i}, b_{R_f}, b_{R_c}, b_{R_o}]
    4) GRU:
        i_t = \sigma(W_i x_t + R_i h_{t-1} + b_{W_i} + b_{R_i})
        r_t = \sigma(W_r x_t + R_r h_{t-1} + b_{W_r} + b_{R_r})
        h^\prime_t = tanh(W_h x_t + r_t \circ (R_h h_{t-1} + b_{R_h}) + b_{W_h})
        h_t = (1 - i_t) \circ h^\prime_t + i_t \circ h_{t-1}

        Parameters: (reset_gate, update_gate, new_mem)
            W_{i2h} = [W_r, W_i, W_h]
            b_{i2h} = [b_{W_r}, b_{W_i}, b_{W_h}]
            W_{h2h} = [R_r, R_i, R_h]
            b_{h2h} = [b_{R_r}, b_{R_i}, b_{R_h}]
    """
```
